R for Medical Research

Filter, group, summarize

Author

Matt Broerman

Published

October 10, 2022

Create Data

Recall this data from last time.

df <- tibble(
  id = c("id01", "id02", "id03", "id01", "id02", "id03"),     
  v1 = rep(c("M", "F", "M"), 2),                          
  v2 = seq(0, 10, by = 2) 
)

df
# A tibble: 6 Ã— 3
  id    v1       v2
  <chr> <chr> <dbl>
1 id01  M         0
2 id02  F         2
3 id03  M         4
4 id01  M         6
5 id02  F         8
6 id03  M        10

Filter

df
# A tibble: 6 Ã— 3
  id    v1       v2
  <chr> <chr> <dbl>
1 id01  M         0
2 id02  F         2
3 id03  M         4
4 id01  M         6
5 id02  F         8
6 id03  M        10
df |> 
  filter(v1 == "M")
# A tibble: 4 Ã— 3
  id    v1       v2
  <chr> <chr> <dbl>
1 id01  M         0
2 id03  M         4
3 id01  M         6
4 id03  M        10
df %>% filter(id %in% c("id01", "id02"))
# A tibble: 4 Ã— 3
  id    v1       v2
  <chr> <chr> <dbl>
1 id01  M         0
2 id02  F         2
3 id01  M         6
4 id02  F         8

Filter

df
# A tibble: 6 Ã— 3
  id    v1       v2
  <chr> <chr> <dbl>
1 id01  M         0
2 id02  F         2
3 id03  M         4
4 id01  M         6
5 id02  F         8
6 id03  M        10
df |> filter(str_detect(id, "03"))
# A tibble: 2 Ã— 3
  id    v1       v2
  <chr> <chr> <dbl>
1 id03  M         4
2 id03  M        10
df_mod <- df
df_mod$v1[4:6] <- NA

df_mod |> filter(is.na(v1))
# A tibble: 3 Ã— 3
  id    v1       v2
  <chr> <chr> <dbl>
1 id01  <NA>      6
2 id02  <NA>      8
3 id03  <NA>     10

Count

Half of data science is counting

df
# A tibble: 6 Ã— 3
  id    v1       v2
  <chr> <chr> <dbl>
1 id01  M         0
2 id02  F         2
3 id03  M         4
4 id01  M         6
5 id02  F         8
6 id03  M        10
df |> 
  count(v1)
# A tibble: 2 Ã— 2
  v1        n
  <chr> <int>
1 F         2
2 M         4
df |> 
  count(v1, sort = TRUE)
# A tibble: 2 Ã— 2
  v1        n
  <chr> <int>
1 M         4
2 F         2

Double up

Surprisingly often, you want to count on counts. But this comes in with big datasets.

df
# A tibble: 6 Ã— 3
  id    v1       v2
  <chr> <chr> <dbl>
1 id01  M         0
2 id02  F         2
3 id03  M         4
4 id01  M         6
5 id02  F         8
6 id03  M        10
df |> 
  count(id) |> 
  count(n)
Storing counts in `nn`, as `n` already present in input
â„¹ Use `name = "new_name"` to pick a new name.
# A tibble: 1 Ã— 2
      n    nn
  <int> <int>
1     2     3

Group

By themselves, groups donâ€™t do much.

df |> group_by(v1)
# A tibble: 6 Ã— 3
# Groups:   v1 [2]
  id    v1       v2
  <chr> <chr> <dbl>
1 id01  M         0
2 id02  F         2
3 id03  M         4
4 id01  M         6
5 id02  F         8
6 id03  M        10
df |> group_by(id, v1)
# A tibble: 6 Ã— 3
# Groups:   id, v1 [3]
  id    v1       v2
  <chr> <chr> <dbl>
1 id01  M         0
2 id02  F         2
3 id03  M         4
4 id01  M         6
5 id02  F         8
6 id03  M        10

Summarise

We use groups with other verbs. Foremost, summarize.

df
# A tibble: 6 Ã— 3
  id    v1       v2
  <chr> <chr> <dbl>
1 id01  M         0
2 id02  F         2
3 id03  M         4
4 id01  M         6
5 id02  F         8
6 id03  M        10
df |> 
  summarize(avg = mean(v2, na.rm = TRUE))
# A tibble: 1 Ã— 1
    avg
  <dbl>
1     5
df |> 
  group_by(v1) |> 
  summarise(average = mean(v2, na.rm = TRUE))
# A tibble: 2 Ã— 2
  v1    average
  <chr>   <dbl>
1 F           5
2 M           5
df |> 
  group_by(id) |> 
  summarise(mean = mean(v2, na.rm = TRUE))
# A tibble: 3 Ã— 2
  id     mean
  <chr> <dbl>
1 id01      3
2 id02      5
3 id03      7

Example

medicaldata::strep_tb |>
  select(patient_id, arm, gender, dose_strep_g, rad_num)
# A tibble: 107 Ã— 5
   patient_id arm     gender dose_strep_g rad_num
   <chr>      <fct>   <fct>         <dbl>   <dbl>
 1 0001       Control M                 0       6
 2 0002       Control F                 0       5
 3 0003       Control F                 0       5
 4 0004       Control M                 0       5
 5 0005       Control F                 0       5
 6 0006       Control M                 0       6
 7 0007       Control F                 0       5
 8 0008       Control M                 0       5
 9 0009       Control F                 0       5
10 0010       Control M                 0       5
# â„¹ 97 more rows

Example

medicaldata::strep_tb |> 
  count(arm, gender)
# A tibble: 4 Ã— 3
  arm          gender     n
  <fct>        <fct>  <int>
1 Streptomycin F         31
2 Streptomycin M         24
3 Control      F         28
4 Control      M         24
medicaldata::strep_tb |> 
  group_by(arm, gender) |> 
  summarise(
    mean_rad_num = mean(rad_num), 
    sd_rad_num = sd(rad_num)
  )
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'arm'. You can override using the `.groups`
argument.
# A tibble: 4 Ã— 4
# Groups:   arm [2]
  arm          gender mean_rad_num sd_rad_num
  <fct>        <fct>         <dbl>      <dbl>
1 Streptomycin F              4.26       1.93
2 Streptomycin M              5.21       1.28
3 Control      F              3.07       1.70
4 Control      M              3.21       1.79
